awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Theoretical Impact of Acquisition Mechanisms on System Design Outcomes Under Uncertainty
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the causes and cures for massive cost overruns in large complex system developments, such as new airplanes, spacecraft, weapon systems or novel energy power plants.  The U.S. Department of Defense reports overruns, delays and cancellations equivalent to $200 million per day in lost value, and similar overruns are experienced by space programs, commercial aircraft, nuclear power plants, and prototype fusion power plants.  Much of these losses are due to engineering processes, but engineering processes are usually a response to customer or government contracts.  Different forms of contracts can bring about different processes, allowing technically ambitious systems to be designed and developed without large losses.  Not only can this save time and money, it will also allow more projects to be attempted, accelerating the speed of technology development and accelerating our nation's economic growth.  This project has the potential to be the basis of change in the Federal acquisition process that could ultimately result in savings exceeding $100 million per day.

The objective of this research project is to test the hypothesis that the mechanism that leads from technical risk and complexity to cost and schedule overruns in large complex engineered systems is the systems engineering process of requirements flow-down, stimulated by requirements-based contracts.  The project will use simulations of engineering organizations to explore the hypothesis.  While many others have applied principle agent theory to contracting, and some have explored principle agent theory within engineering organizations, this is the first project to investigate how to optimize incentive contracts to affect the systems engineering structure of design work within a large engineering organization. It is the interaction of the contract and the way systems engineering is conducted that marks truly new ground in this research. The project explores four research questions: 1) What is the causal relationship among cost reimbursement, award fees, incentives, and project outcomes? 2) How is this relationship affected by the structural complexity and size of the industry engineering organization, including the supply chain? 3) How is this relationship affected by program uncertainty, particularly technical risk? 4) How is this relationship affected by uncertainty in the user environment, that is, by out year changes in the relationship of artifact attributes to government benefit?   Answering these questions will expose theoretical issues pertaining to acquisitions in systems engineering that are poorly understood today.

por.por_cntn:
The federal government loses over $300M a day due to LSCES cancellations, project delays, and project overruns. In this research project, the effects of endogenous and exogenous influences on the cost overrun of large-scale complex engineered systems (LSCES) have been investigated. The outcomes of this research project are new methods and tools that enable managers of LSCES to understand the effects of endogenous and exogenous system parameters, and to approximately predict, within given uncertainty bounds, their effects in the near term. Specifically, a simulation-based and data-driven framework for global sensitivity analysis, inversion, and cost prediction and uncertainty analysis has been created. In forward analysis, the framework simulates the LSCES using physics-based models combined with cost models to estimate the performance and cost for a given design and performance period. The approach was demonstrated on the advanced extremely high-frequency satellite system program and use public data from selected acquisition reports (SARs). The computational framework for the following cases: (1) the model is used in forward analysis mode to estimate the sensitivities to reveal the system parameters having the most effect on the output, which is the cost in our demonstration cases, (2) the simulation model is used in forward analysis mode and combined with inversion algorithms, as well as the available cost SAR data, to quantify the uncertainty distributions of the input parameters, (3) the simulation model is used in forward analysis mode and combined with a subset of the SAR cost data using fusion-based surrogate modeling to predict the system cost, as the uncertainty in the prediction, for the next cycles. The impact of this research project on systems engineering are the creation of the novel computational framework described in this report which assist managers to understand the effects of endogenous and exogenous system parameters on large-scale complex systems, and to approximately predict, within given uncertainty bounds, their effects in the near term. These approaches can therefore facilitate an improved cost-control of large-scale projects which allows for mitigation of cost overruns under uncertainty. The computational framework is general and can be used for other complex systems than the satellite system program used in this work. Therefore, it is expected that the outcomes of this research work will have relevance in other engineering disciplines. If even some of the cost overruns of the federal government can be prevented, there will be a significant impact on society as these resources could then be better used.
